question: Linked lists allow dynamic memory allocation, meaning their size does not need to be defined in advance.
Arrays are more flexible than linked lists when it comes to inserting and deleting elements.
A linked list consists of nodes, where each node contains data and a pointer to the next node.
Stacks and queues cannot be implemented using linked lists.
In a stack implemented using a linked list, the last element added is the first one to be removed.
A doubly linked list is used to implement web browser history navigation.
Hash tables use linked lists to handle collisions when two keys have the same hash value.
Music playlists are commonly implemented using singly linked lists.
In an undo/redo system, actions are stored using a queue-based structure.
Operating systems use linked lists to manage memory allocation and fragmentation.
A circular linked list is commonly used in operating system scheduling algorithms.
Linked lists can shrink or grow as needed, unlike arrays which have a fixed size.
The front of a queue implemented with a linked list is called the top.
In a linked list, memory allocation is contiguous like in arrays.
Linked lists are inefficient in scenarios where random access is required.
A node in a doubly linked list contains two pointers.
In a singly linked list, each node has a pointer to the previous node.
A stack can be implemented using a linked list by inserting and deleting elements only from the head.
Queues are implemented using the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle.
In a circular linked list, the last node points back to the first node.
Linked lists are ideal for applications requiring frequent insertions and deletions.
In a singly linked list, traversal is only possible in one direction.
A linked list cannot be used to implement hash tables.
Social media friend connections can be represented using a graph where linked lists store relationships.
A doubly linked list can be traversed in both forward and backward directions.
A linked list uses less memory per node compared to an array because it doesn't store pointers.
A singly linked list is more memory-efficient than a doubly linked list.
Web browsers use linked lists to store and navigate browsing history.
A linked list node contains both data and an address of the next node.
Circular linked lists are never used in real-world applications.
The time complexity of inserting an element at the beginning of a linked list is O(1).
The time complexity of accessing an element at a random position in a linked list is O(1).
Linked lists are more efficient than arrays for direct indexing operations.
Undo/Redo functionality in text editors is implemented using linked lists.
In a hash table, a linked list can be used to store multiple values that hash to the same index.
A doubly linked list uses two pointers per node, increasing memory usage compared to a singly linked list.
A circular linked list can be used to implement a round-robin scheduling algorithm.
Stacks operate based on the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
A circular linked list has a NULL pointer at the end of the list.
Inserting an element at the end of a linked list requires traversal in the worst case.
Deleting a node from the middle of a singly linked list requires modifying at most one pointer.
A linked list is always more memory-efficient than an array.
A circular doubly linked list allows traversal in both directions without a NULL reference.
Adding an element to a linked list is always O(1) regardless of position.
A linked list does not support direct access to elements via indexing.
A linked list is a linear data structure.
Hash tables are used in databases and search engines to store key-value pairs efficiently.
Linked lists can be used to efficiently implement a graph's adjacency list representation.
A queue implemented with a linked list supports efficient O(1) insertion and deletion.
In linked lists, memory is allocated in contiguous blocks.
